intro: Bassia wilsonii, commonly known as Wilson's knotweed, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Amaranthaceae family and is characterized by its erect, branched stems and small, clustered flowers. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers that are typically arranged in dense clusters at the ends of the stems. Its leaves are lance-shaped and often covered in fine hairs, giving the plant a distinctive appearance. Bassia wilsonii is adapted to arid environments and is often found in disturbed soils and rocky areas.
